sen.j: 星 亨（ほし とおる、嘉永3年4月8日_(旧暦)（1850年5月19日） - 明治34年（1901年）6月21日）は、明治時代の政治家（「星享」は誤表記）。
sen.e: Toru HOSHI (May 19th, 1850 - June 21st, 1901), was a statesman during the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: I translated the terms on this row differently to suit the context
sen.e: Toru HOSHI (May 19, 1850 - June 21, 1901), was a statesman in the Meiji period (The kanji letter '享' often used for his first name Toru '亨' is incorrect).
sen.cmt: 訳抜けの最後の()の中を訳出しました。日付表記の変更をしました。During をinに変更しました。
sen.e: Toru HOSHI (May 19, 1850 - June 21, 1901), was a statesman in the Meiji period (The kanji letter '享' often used for his first name Toru '亨' is incorrect).

sen.j: 江戸の左官屋として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born to a plasterer in Edo Prefecture.
He was born to a plasterer's family in Edo.
sen.cmt: plastererをplasterer's familyとしました。Prefecture を削除しました、
sen.e: He was born to a plasterer's family in Edo.

sen.j: 父が行方不明となり、母が星泰順と結婚し、星姓を名乗る。
sen.e: His father went missing, after which his mother remarried Taijun HOSHI; his last name changed to HOSHI.
Since his father went missing and his mother remarried Taijun HOSHI, his family name was changed to HOSHI.
sen.cmt: TaijunとHOSHIの間のスペースを全角から半角にしました。
sen.e: Since his father went missing and his mother remarried Taijun HOSHI, his family name was changed to HOSHI.

sen.j: 当初は医学を志していたが、英学に転向し、何礼之の元で英学を学び、後に英語教師として身を立てる。
sen.e: At first, he aspired to study medical science, but changed his interest to English; he studied English under Noriyuki GA, and established himself as an English teacher.
At first, he aspired to study medical science, but changed his interest to English; he studied English under Noriyuki GA, and established himself as an English teacher.
At first, he aspired to study medical science, but changed his interest to English; he studied English under Noriyuki GA, and established himself as an English teacher.

sen.j: 明治維新の後には陸奥宗光の推挙で明治政府に入り、一時横浜市税関長となるが、英国のクイーンを「女王」と訳し、「女皇」と訳すべしとするイギリス公使ハリー・パークスの抗議に、自説を主張し一歩も譲らず、いわゆる「女王事件」を引き起こし、引責辞任した。
sen.e: After the Meiji restoration, he joined the Meiji government with recommendation from Munemitsu MUTSU, and for a time was the Yokohama City's chief customs inspector, but he translated the British "Queen" as 女王=>princess; Princess (the title given to an imperial lady of legitimate birth in the male line within three generations and without the imperial proclamation for an entitlement of an Imperial Princess), and was adamant against British ambassador Harry Parks, who translated Queen to 女皇(empress), causing the "Queen incident", subsequently resigning.

Although he joined the Meiji government with recommendation from Munemitsu MUTSU after the Meiji Restoration and served as director of the customs office in Yokohama City for a while, he resigned from the post taking responsibility for the 'Queen incident' over Japanese translation for British "Queen" which he insisted on translating it into the Japanese word "女王" (female king) and refused to accept the opinion of British ambassador Harry Parks who protested against HOSHI's translation and insisted on translating it into 女皇(empress).
sen.cmt: butの前後関係が不自然です。全文書換えました。
sen.e: Although he joined the Meiji government with recommendation from Munemitsu MUTSU after the Meiji Restoration and served as director of the customs office in Yokohama City for a while, he resigned from the post taking responsibility for the 'Queen incident' over Japanese translation for British "Queen" which he insisted on translating it into the Japanese word "女王" (female king) and refused to accept the opinion of British ambassador Harry Parks who protested against HOSHI's translation and insisted on translating it into 女皇(empress).

sen.j: 辞任後、法律研究のためイギリスに渡り、日本人初の法廷弁護士資格を取得した。
sen.e: After resigning, he moved to England to study law, and became the first Japanese to obtain a law license.
After resigning, HOSHI moved to England to study law, and became the first Japanese to become a qualified barrister.
sen.cmt: migrateをmoveにしました。またlaw lisenceでは抽象的過ぎますので最後のto以下を書き換えました。
sen.e: After resigning, HOSHI moved to England to study law, and became the first Japanese to become a qualified barrister.

sen.j: 帰国後は国内で司法省付属代言人（弁護士）の第1号となって活躍し、明治14年（1881年）には自由党(明治)の議員（代議士）となり、政党政治の基礎作りの一翼を担った。
sen.e: After returning to Japan, he became the first lawyer under the Ministry of Justice, and in 1881, he became a councilor (as parliamentarian) of the Liberal party, and took part in building the foundation of party government.

After returning to Japan, HOSHI became the first lawyer under the Ministry of Justice and actively worked in Japan, and in 1881, he became a councilor (as parliamentarian) of the Liberal Party, and took part in building the foundation of party government.
sen.cmt: 訳抜け：「活躍し」→and actively worked in Japanを追加しました。
sen.e: After returning to Japan, HOSHI became the first lawyer under the Ministry of Justice and actively worked in Japan, and in 1881, he became a councilor (as parliamentarian) of the Liberal Party, and took part in building the foundation of party government.

sen.j: 藩閥政治を批判し、明治20年（1887年）の三大事件建白運動に参加し、保安条例で東京を追われ、出版条例違反で投獄される。
sen.e: He was critical of majority politics, and in 1887, participated in the san daiji (three essential doctrines in shingon sect) petition movement; he was exiled from Tokyo Prefecture under hoan jorei (regulations for the preservation of law and order), then was arrested for violation of publication regulations.

Being critical of the oligarchic government dominated by hanbatsu (domain cliques), HOSHI participated in the political campaign called Sandaijikenpaku Undo (a movement triggered by the petition calling for establishment of three pillars) in 1887, but he was driven out of Tokyo according to hoan jorei (regulations for the preservation of law and order) and then was arrested for violation of publication regulations.
sen.cmt: 不適当な訳文です。藩閥の訳が不適当のほか、三大事はここでは仏教とは関係ない、または真言宗をここで言及する必要はない、と思われます。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: Being critical of the oligarchic government dominated by hanbatsu (domain cliques), HOSHI participated in the political campaign called Sandaijikenpaku Undo (a movement triggered by the petition calling for establishment of three pillars) in 1887, but he was driven out of Tokyo according to hoan jorei (regulations for the preservation of law and order) and then was arrested for violation of publication regulations.

sen.j: 釈放後の明治25年（1892年）には自らの衆議院議長就任を公約として第2回衆議院議員総選挙に出馬、当選。
sen.e: After being released, under condition that he will assume position as chairman of House of Representatives, he ran for in the second House election, and was elected.

After being released, HOSHI ran for the 2nd general election of the House of Representatives in 1892, with a campaign pledge that he would become chairman of the House of Representatives, and was elected as a parliament member.
sen.cmt: 不適当な訳文です。「公約」をconditionと訳すべきではないほか、後半は語法の誤りがあります。年号も抜けています。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: After being released, HOSHI ran for the 2nd general election of the House of Representatives in 1892, with a campaign pledge that he would become chairman of the House of Representatives, and was elected as a parliament member.

sen.j: 公約どおり2代目議長に選ばれる。
sen.e: As promised, he was appointed the second Chairman.
He was appointed as the second chairman of the Lower House, thereby fulfilling his promise.
sen.cmt: 後半は語法の誤りがあります。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: He was appointed as the second chairman of the Lower House, thereby fulfilling his promise.

sen.j: 明治26年（1893年）に相馬事件の収賄疑惑によって議長不信任案が可決される。
sen.e: In 1893, he was accused of accepting bribes in the Souba incident, and there was a vote of non-confidence against him.
In 1893, the parliament passed a no-confidence motion against chairman HOSHI who was suspected of having received bribes in the Soma Incident.
sen.cmt: 不適当な訳文です。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。「可決」が訳出されていません。相馬はsoubaでなくsomaと読むようです。全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: In 1893, the parliament passed a no-confidence motion against chairman HOSHI who was suspected of having received bribes in the Soma Incident.

sen.j: しかし、議長を不信任となったにも関わらず議長席への着席に固執したため、衆議院から除名された。
sen.e: However, even after the vote of non-confidence, he refused to give up his position, and was expelled from the House of Representatives.
However, since HOSHI refused to give up his position as chairman even after the non-confidence motion was passed, he was expelled from the House of Representatives.
sen.cmt: 文の接続関係を明確にするため接続詞sinceを用いる文に書き換えました。
sen.e: However, since HOSHI refused to give up his position as chairman even after the non-confidence motion was passed, he was expelled from the House of Representatives.

sen.j: 次回選挙で当選し、政界に復帰する。
sen.e: He ran in the next election, and won, returning to the political arena.
He ran in the next election, and won, returning to the political arena.
He ran in the next election, and won, returning to the political arena.

sen.j: 藩閥政治に対する批判者であったが、非藩閥の陸奥宗光からは引き続き可愛がられ、朝鮮政府の法律顧問や駐米公使を務める。
sen.e: He criticized majority politics, but he was on amicable terms with Munemitsu MUTSU, who was anti-domain clique politics, and served as law advisor to the Korean government, and also as an ambassador to the United States.

Munemitsu MUTSU, not a member of hanbatsu, continued to favor HOSHI who was critical of the oligarchic government dominated by hanbatsu, and HOSHI served as law advisor to the Korean government, and also as a minister-counselor to the United States.
sen.cmt: 陸奥宗光は反藩閥でしたが、ここでは「非藩閥」とのみ書かれているのでanti-は原文の意味から多少ずれてしまいます。「引き続き」が訳出されていません。前半を書き換えたほか、「公使」：an ambassadorを a minister-counselorとしました。
sen.e: Munemitsu MUTSU, not a member of hanbatsu, continued to favor HOSHI who was critical of the oligarchic government dominated by hanbatsu, and HOSHI served as law advisor to the Korean government, and also as a minister-counselor to the United States.

sen.j: 第1次大隈内閣では外務大臣 (日本)として入閣する予定であったが、内閣総理大臣の大隈重信がこれを拒否したために憲政党分裂の原因を作った。
sen.e: In the first OKUMA cabinet (Japan), he was scheduled to serve as Minister of Foreign Affairs, but the Prime Minister Shigenobu OKUMA denied it, which caused the Ken party to split.
Although HOSHI was supposed to become Japan's Minister of Foreign Affairs in the first OKUMA cabinet, Prime Minister Shigenobu OKUMA refused it, which caused the Kenseito party to split up.
sen.cmt: 「憲政党」の訳が適当でない他、不適当な訳文です。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: Although HOSHI was supposed to become Japan's Minister of Foreign Affairs in the first OKUMA cabinet, Prime Minister Shigenobu OKUMA refused it, which caused the Kenseito party to split up.

sen.j: 第4次伊藤内閣において逓信大臣などを務めた。
sen.e: Under Prime Minister ITO, he served as the Minister of Communications.
In the fourth ITO cabinet, he took positions such as the Minister of Communication.
sen.cmt: [伊藤内閣]の訳が不適当です。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: In the fourth ITO cabinet, he took positions such as the Minister of Communication.

sen.j: 明治33年（1900年）発足の立憲政友会にも参加、伊藤博文からも信頼を受けるようになる。
sen.e: In 1900, he participated in the inauguration of Rikken-seiyuu party, and gained trust from Hirobumi ITO.
HOSHI joined Rikken Seiyukai party established in 1900, and gained trust from Hirobumi ITO.
sen.cmt: 「1900年」は「発足」にかかるので、前半の訳文が不適当です。書き換えました。
sen.e: HOSHI joined Rikken Seiyukai party established in 1900, and gained trust from Hirobumi ITO.

sen.j: その逞しい政治手腕から「おしとおる」とあだ名された位だった。
sen.e: Due to his dependable capability in politics, he was nicknamed "Oshitoru" (to have one's way)
He had so aggressive political skills that he was nicknamed "Oshitoru" (to have one's way).
sen.cmt: 前半の訳文が不適当です。ほぼ全文書換えとしました。またピリオドを追加しました。
sen.e: He had so aggressive political skills that he was nicknamed "Oshitoru" (to have one's way).

sen.j: 星は、積極財政をすすめて地域への利益誘導をはかり、支持獲得を目指す積極主義という政治手法をとった。
sen.e: HOSHI promoted positive fiscal policy, allocating the budgets more in country side, and hoped to gain wide recognition and support.

HOSHI took a positive political approach in which he promoted an expansionary fiscal policy to develop pork barrel politics, trying to obtain appropriations for his own district, with an aim to gain support.
sen.cmt: 後半が不適当です。全文書換えとしました。
sen.e: HOSHI took a positive political approach in which he promoted an expansionary fiscal policy to develop pork barrel politics, trying to obtain appropriations for his own district, with an aim to gain support.

sen.j: 一方で収賄などの噂も絶えず、日本の政党政治と利益誘導の構造すなわち金権型政党政治を築いたとされる。
sen.e: On the other hand, the rumors of him taking bribes never ceased; he is known to have established corruption in the Japanese government.

On the other hand, HOSHI was always rumored to take bribes, and thus he is said to have established the Japan's party politics combined with pork barrel politics, in other words, the money-driven political system.
sen.cmt: 「利益誘導の構造すなわち金権型政党政治」の部分がcorruption一語で訳出されており、不適当な訳文です。また「政党政治」の訳出がありません。全文書き換えとしました。
sen.e: On the other hand, HOSHI was always rumored to take bribes, and thus he is said to have established the Japan's party politics combined with pork barrel politics, in other words, the money-driven political system.

sen.j: 日本裏面史より見れば、三多摩の村野常右衛門、森久保作蔵など「大阪事件」以降の自由党右派の壮士たちを政界に引き入れたことで、たとえ星自身が金銭的に潔白であるとしても、東京市政の疑獄の数々には彼の責も大きいと言われる。
sen.e: Looking back at the darker side of Japanese history, HOSHI led Uemon MURANOJO of Santama City, Seizo MORIKUBO, among other Liberals involved in the Osaka Incident, and therefore, even if he himself was innocent of taking bribes, he is still partly responsible for the numerous scandals in Tokyo city politics.

From the darker side of Japanese history, HOSHI, who brought into the political world rightists of the Liberal Party after the 'Osaka Incident,' including young activists called Santama Soshi such as Tsuneemon MURANO and Sakuzo MORIKUBO, is said to have been heavily to blame for the numerous scandals in Tokyo municipal government.
sen.cmt: 村野常右衛門 森久保作蔵:人名の読み方が違います。 三多摩、自由党右派の壮士たち: 訳が全く違います。 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: From the darker side of Japanese history, HOSHI, who brought into the political world rightists of the Liberal Party after the 'Osaka Incident,' including young activists called Santama Soshi such as Tsuneemon MURANO and Sakuzo MORIKUBO, is said to have been heavily to blame for the numerous scandals in Tokyo municipal government.

sen.j: 東京市議会議長であった明治34年（1901年）、伊庭想太郎（心形刀流第10代宗家）により市庁参事会室内で刺殺された。
sen.e: In 1901, when he was the Tokyo City's Assembly Chairman, he was stabbed and killed by Soutaro IBA (of the 10th generation Shingyoto-ryu kenjutsu (classical sword tradition) family)

In 1901, when he was chairman of Tokyo City Assembly, he was stabbed to death by Sotaro IBA (the 10th head of Shingyoto-ryu swordplay school) at the Tokyo city council's room in the city government office.
sen.cmt: 訳ぬけ：市庁参事会室内、宗家 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: In 1901, when he was chairman of Tokyo City Assembly, he was stabbed to death by Sotaro IBA (the 10th head of Shingyoto-ryu swordplay school) at the Tokyo city council's room in the city government office.

sen.j: 享年51。
sen.e: He died at age 51.
He died at age 51.
He died at age 51.

sen.j: 明治25年（1892年）11月29日、当時衆議院議長であった星に対する議長不信任案が166対119で可決された。
sen.e: In November 29th, 1892, there was a vote of non-confidence again HOSHI, who was Chairman of the House of Representatives at the time.
On November 29, 1892, a non-confidence motion against HOSHI who was chairman of the House of Representatives at that time was passed by a vote of 166 to 119.
sen.cmt: In November 29th→On November 29 166対119:訳抜け 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: On November 29, 1892, a non-confidence motion against HOSHI who was chairman of the House of Representatives at that time was passed by a vote of 166 to 119.

sen.j: だが、星はこれを「条約改正を支持する自分に対する硬六派（国民協会_(日本)・立憲改進党ら）による嫌がらせでやましい所はない」として、これを拒否した（大日本帝国憲法下の議院法では衆議院議長は勅任官の扱いを受けて天皇に任免権があった）。
sen.e: However, HOSHI interpreted this as harassment by the Japanese Citizens Association/ The Constitutional Progressive Party who opposed his support for treaty amendment, and claimed innocence, denying all accusations (As stated in the Constitution, the House of representatives Chairman was appointed by the Emperor).

However, HOSHI alleged this as harassment by Koroppa (the hard-line six parties, consisting of Kokumin Kyokai (National Association), the Constitutional Progressive Party and others) opposing him who supports for amendments of treaties, and claimed his own innocence, refusing to give up his position (according to the parliamentary law under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan, the Emperor had rights to appoint and dismiss chairman of the House of representatives).
sen.cmt: 大日本帝国, 議員法、天皇に任免権があった :全て訳抜け
sen.e: However, HOSHI alleged this as harassment by Koroppa (the hard-line six parties, consisting of Kokumin Kyokai (National Association), the Constitutional Progressive Party and others) opposing him who supports for amendments of treaties, and claimed his own innocence, refusing to give up his position (according to the parliamentary law under the Constitution of the Empire of Japan, the Emperor had rights to appoint and dismiss chairman of the House of representatives).

sen.j: そこで明治天皇に対して星の解任を求める上奏を152対126で可決した。
sen.e: Then, the House voted 152 to 126 to request HOSHI's dismissal to the Emperor.
Then, the House voted 152 yea to 126 nay to submit a report to the throne for asking the Meiji Emperor to dismiss HOSHI.
sen.cmt: 明治:訳抜け 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: Then, the House voted 152 yea to 126 nay to submit a report to the throne for asking the Meiji Emperor to dismiss HOSHI.

sen.j: だが、天皇からは「議院自ら不明なりしとの過失」として衆議院の怠慢を責める勅答が下された（これは、星への不信任を当時外務大臣 (日本)であった陸奥宗光への間接的攻撃とみた伊藤博文が土方久元宮内大臣に要請して出させたものとされている）。
sen.e: However, the Emperor replied, "There is nothing to prove the councilors' innocence either," and blamed their negligence. (It is believed that Hirobumi ITO who saw HOSHI's non-confidence as an indirect attack towards Munemitsu MUTSU, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, requested this reply from the Minister of Imperial Court)

The Emperor's reply to this motion, however, blamed the House of Representatives as negligent, saying 'the House itself is unclear and has erred' (it is believed that Hirobumi ITO, who regarded the non-confidence motion as an indirect attack towards Munemitsu MUTSU, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, asked Imperial Household Minister Hisamoto HIJIKATA to issue such a reply).
sen.cmt: 土方久元宮内大臣:訳抜け 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: The Emperor's reply to this motion, however, blamed the House of Representatives as negligent, saying 'the House itself is unclear and has erred' (it is believed that Hirobumi ITO, who regarded the non-confidence motion as an indirect attack towards Munemitsu MUTSU, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, asked Imperial Household Minister Hisamoto HIJIKATA to issue such a reply).

sen.j: そのため、星は尚も議長席に着席して議長の職務を続けようとした。
sen.e: Therefore, HOSHI attempted to continue his duties as Chairman.
Therefore, HOSHI attempted to continue his duties as Chairman.
Therefore, HOSHI attempted to continue his duties as Chairman.

sen.j: このため、12月5日には星の登院停止1週間処分の決議が出された。
sen.e: For this reason, on December 5th, the House voted to have him suspended for a week.
Against this, the House voted to have him suspended from the parliament for a week on December 5.
sen.cmt: ほぼ全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: Against this, the House voted to have him suspended from the parliament for a week on December 5.

sen.j: だが、登院停止が切れた12月12日に星はまたも議長席に座ろうとした。
sen.e: However, after his suspension, HOSHI tried to return to his position.
However, on December 12, the day after his suspension period expired, HOSHI again tried to take the seat on chairman.
sen.cmt: 12月12日：訳抜け 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: However, on December 12, the day after his suspension period expired, HOSHI again tried to take the seat on chairman.

sen.j: そこで12月13日に懲罰にかけられて185対92で除名要件である三分の二を超える67％の賛成を得たため、除名処分となり、衆議院議員の資格を失った星は自動的に議長を解任された。
sen.e: He was put on trial on December 13th, and was expelled due to a 185 to 92 vote, which exceeded the necessary 67% (2/3); after losing his seat in the House, he automatically lost his position as Chairman as well.

On December 13, a motion calling for disciplinary action against HOSHI was passed by a vote of 185 yea to 92 nay, approved by 67 % which exceeded two-thirds votes required for expelling him from the parliament and therefore, HOSHI lost his seat in the House, automatically losing his position as chairman as well.
sen.cmt: 懲罰:trialは不適当な訳出です。全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: On December 13, a motion calling for disciplinary action against HOSHI was passed by a vote of 185 yea to 92 nay, approved by 67 % which exceeded two-thirds votes required for expelling him from the parliament and therefore, HOSHI lost his seat in the House, automatically losing his position as chairman as well.

sen.j: 墓所は東京大田区の本門寺に所在。
sen.e: He was buried in a graveyard in Ota ward, Tokyo Prefecture.
His grave is at Honmon-ji Temple located in Ota ward, Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 本門寺:訳抜け 全体を書き換えました。
sen.e: His grave is at Honmon-ji Temple located in Ota ward, Tokyo.

There was once a bronze statue of HOSHI in the precincts of Honmon-ji Temple, but since the government collected metals during World War II, the statue was removed from its pedestal.

sen.e: There was once a bronze statue of HOSHI in the precincts of Honmon-ji Temple, but since the government collected metals during World War II, the statue was removed from its pedestal.

sen.j: 戦後、遺族により台座は本門寺に寄進され、現在は日蓮上人の像が置かれている。
sen.e: In the post war period, the pedestal was donated to Honmo-ji temple by his relatives, and today, a statue of The Venerable Nichiren can be seen standing on it.
